body:
Just a reminder that this eye opening thing exists. 

Credit goes to PlatTwoIsHell

"I'm a 20 year old college student and two days ago I was paid to watch over a few kids while their parents were away. It turns out three of them played league and since I brought my laptop with me, we decided to play some normals together. I only played two games before I forced myself to stop. It was one of the most traumatic experiences I've ever had.
Game 1: I went syndra mid while the kids went elsewhere. Within 10 minutes I was 3-0 in lane, while they all died a few times. I didn't think much of it since I'm platinum and they were bronze. However, they all started blaming each other and the one random we had on our team. They raged at everything. The lagg, their fps, their ping, everything besides themselves. Two of them ragequit before we could surrender and the game was over before 20 minutes.
Game 2: Same start, except this time two of them couldn't connect due to the "firewall" error. I took a look at their computers to see what the problem was. I couldn't believe the amount of malware and incorrectly chosen settings they had. All they did was blame riot and riot's servers when their complete lack of knowledge about anything related to computers was the problem. I'm not a computer science major myself, but I can at least keep league running fine unless riot's servers crash (in which case everyone disconnects).
Before that day, I thought that people who went afk had legitimate reasons to do so. However, I now realize that most of these afks have severe self control problems and lack basic knowledge about computers and how the internet works. Also, I used to believe that ragers were people who've had a bad day. Now I'm inclined to believe that they're just young, spoiled kids. Before this incident I thought that plat soloQ was bad, but now I feel lucky that I don't have it worse. It must be hell in bronze and silver. I hope that riot will somehow address this problem. Maybe they can force constant afkers to take lessons on computer maintenance, or maybe they will implement a form of age verification similar to Korea. I don't know what is the best solution, but I now understand why several of my college peers stopped playing league entirely."

Coincidence? I think not!

Simply put, kids ruin games. Straight up from what you said, but also because the fact that they ask parents to pay for DLC and things like RP without a second thought b/c they see their parents money as endless supplies of money, and not as an exhaustible resource. They don't contemplate the worth of the things they buy because they don't pay for it. So when they buy shit content and overpriced in-game goods like RP, this encourages companies to continue to put out cheap bullshit because it WILL sell.

I wish games had a way to verify age like you must upload some type of verification like a driver's license. Then you could be put into 18+ servers. Even if the kids somehow stole a parent's there still would be far less kids online. No I.D.? that's okay, you just will have to play with the kids.

While I agree with all of your points, adding a system like that would do more harm than it would good for the rest of us below 18. Generalizing is always necessary to fix an issue that affects more than one person, but it doesn't mean it should be implemented if there are too many people *being* generalized. I'm under 18, work for all of my money, try to stay as positive as possible in Silver V, and I haven't left a game in over 4 months (pre-4 months ago, I was part of the group that was forced to leave by parents, referring to an earlier thread on here about that). I binge heavily on RP and the like, but it's the only thing currently that I find worth it, even if I am in a lower ELO with little reason to buy it other than for cosmetic pleasure. Sure, just because I'm an exception from the group doesn't mean a system based off of age is a bad idea and that it *shouldn't* be a reality, but if it was, it prevents me and the people like me from playing and enjoying the game as well.

There's a difference between bad players who are inherently bad and refuse to change to be better, and bad people who are willing and trying to learn. Let's say there's a ratio of 1/4 latter/former. If it's only four people playing, then sure, kick out the one kid. It's one person, and cynical as it may sound, who cares about him. The other three are happier now. But if the ratio is something like 2 million/8 million, then it's far too many people to make unhappy. 

Don't misunderstand me, I severely dislike the high RP costs. I'm just in a position where I don't mind spending $50 every month or so.
I mean, shit, if the toxic spoiled kids actually got banned then it wouldn't be an issue.

Though people forget that while that those kids are the issue, a few bad apples spoil the bunch as they say. It's not exactly fair either way to anyone in the end, though parents should really have a tighter reign on their children these days...
I wouldn't say kids as much as immature people.  there are tons of kids out there who are surprisingly mature and tons of adults out there who are ridiculously immature.

Putting all the kids together can actually amplify the issue. They are even more likely then to not come into contact with the supposedly more mature 18+ crowd, and instead come into more contact with others with identical maturity issues. The manifestations of negative behaviour reinforce each other and spiral into a classic "Prisoner's Island" problem.

I'm not so sure the problem is that 11-14 year-olds act this way. They're not mature. They're literally acting like children, which is what they are.

The problem is the millions of adults that act exactly like these 11-14 year-olds, because they never learned anything from experiences like these when they had them at that age. 

At that point, they're out of excuses and should be ashamed of themselves, and in a perfect world, banned from the internet until they finally did learn how to act like adults.

I can't understand why there is so little tolerance for kids here. They are allowed to be chilidsh, and they are allowed to make mistakes.

At the end of the day League of Legends is a game, unless you play it professionally and actually get paid for it, or are aiming to make this your job.

It is mostly because this game is rated T, and as such should not be played by 11 year olds. 11 year olds are certainly allowed to make mistakes, but when the game advertises itself for teens and up, you don't expect to get that level of immaturity. To be fair, there are of course exceptions, like the 30 year old who rages, or the eloquent teen player who is polite all match, but the point is that *in general* you can expect a higher degree of maturity from older players because they are by definition, more mature. It isn't that people don't like kids, it is that they come to this environment expecting one thing (a mature friendly atmosphere), and end up with an unpleasant surprise in some situations (and remember, this is completely NOT for the purpose of making a universal statement that kids are not fun to play with, I'm just trying to explain their reasoning).

to expect a mature atmosphere in any online game, no matter the rating, is kind of naive. This is my personal experience of course.
Furthermore the "T" -Rating  is for 13 year olds and above. I wouldn't expect much maturity from a 13 year old...
Which means that people don't really have a right to complain.

Please don't misunderstand me. I understand why so many are unhappy about kids acting like .. kids, but I also think that we as humans are able to overlook things. We get to decide what is important, and what is not. A lost **game** (for whatever reason) should not matter, but for some reason people have decided that this topic is very important for them. And it's my personal opinion, that it is not.

That is just your low standard for human behavior. I am a teen, yet I behave responsibly and maturely, where most people seem to think that is out of the ordinary. I agree though that a key part of acting maturely is the ability to also overlook other's immaturity as well.

It is generally provable that people in the lower teens and below don't have a strong grasp on emotional maturity and have often not mastered many of those tools. Likewise it has been shown those in the 16-26 range, particularly males, have a challenge mastering empathy which is why so much trollish and ego centric behavior is seen there. But it is further easily provable that those older than that can suffer from one or both of these issues and those younger can master them.

So my point, to all those who have overcome and risen above the common denominators of your age to be great players and teammates in the contexts of maturity, integrity and empathy. My thanks to you!
I just wanna know what is the basic computer skills are to fix the "firewall" problem...
You give LoL permission via your firewall so its not blocking incoming, outgoing traffic.

That is how to solve *a firewall problem*, not how to solve *the "firewall" problem*. The latter is, I assure you, caused by Riot.

(As much as any compatibility issue is caused by developers, which is to say it may be someone else's fault but it is an issue that happens with their product and in their best interest to find a workaround.)

All online games have the firewall problem because they send and receive unsecured packets to help reduce lag, Firewalls detect these and will stop them for your safety, hence why you have to tell it to allow them through. Antiviruses are a problem for much the same reason.

There is no workaround that does not cause lag as the only workaround is to secure the packets, forcing your router to properly process and verify everything, causing significant lag.

Just be glad you don't have to open ports on your router to play. 

This is not Riot's fault and has been an issue since playing online.
To anyone reading this, go into your antivirus settings and add the "C:\Riot Games" path to the exclusions. Practically nobody knows about this but it solves patcher and in-game issues

No, *the "firewall" problem* is not that. It is likely not connected to firewalls at all, that's simply the error it gives. I already explained that it's not exactly Riot's *fault* but it is not a user issue.
